The development of green, efficient, and economical catalysts for the transformation of biomass into value-added chemicals is vital for advancing sustainable chemical manufacturing. In this work, a series of cost-effective and stable zirconium-based catalysts were synthesized via coordination of Zr4+ with malic acid (MA), a low-cost and naturally abundant organic ligand, in aqueous solution. By precisely tuning the ligand-to-metal molar ratio, the porous structure properties of the resulting materials could be finely controlled. In addition, the Brønsted-to-Lewis acid site ratio reached 0.37, indicating a well-balanced acidic environment. These structural and acidic characteristics collectively contributed to its superior catalytic performance in the conversion of ethyl levulinate (EL) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) via transfer hydrogenation and intramolecular lactonization. Kinetic analysis revealed that elevated temperatures promote the direct transformation of EL to GVL; however, temperatures beyond the optimal range induce competing transesterification reactions, thereby extending the reaction pathway. Notably, the catalyst retained its activity over at least six consecutive cycles without detectable deactivation. A mechanistic framework is proposed to provide deeper insight into the transfer hydrogenation process mediated by this class of Zr-based coordination catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Ethyl levulinate Γ-valerolactone Catalytic transfer hydrogenation Kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The catalytic conversion of renewable biomass into chemicals and biofuels represents one of the most promising approaches for achieving carbon neutrality and mitigating dependence on fossil energy sources [1–3]. γ-valerolactone (GVL), as a versatile bio-based platform chemical, serves not only as a green solvent and biofuel [4,5], but also as a key intermediate for the synthesis of widely used polymer precursors, such as 1,4-butanediol and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran [6]. Owing to these multifunctional attributes, GVL holds great promise for broad applications in various industrial sectors [7]. The synthesis of GVL from bio-derived levulinate has attracted considerable attention in recent years [8,9]. The conversion of levulinate to GVL can be accomplished via two principal approaches: direct hydrogenation using H2 or catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) [10,11]. In the CTH pathway, formic acid and secondary alcohols, such as methanol, ethanol, 2-butanol, and isopropanol, serve as hydrogen donors [12]. Compared with conventional hydrogen gas hydrogenation, transfer hydrogenation proceeds under milder reaction conditions and offers simpler operational procedures [13]. Moreover, in heterogeneous catalytic systems, it enables favorable selectivity and high yields [14,15]. In addition, the hydrogen source material used, such as isopropanol, can be produced through biomass fermentation (such as corn or sugarcane), which is renewable and low in toxicity, complementing the green design of bio-based malic acid ligands. In addition to the aforementioned advantages of the CTH reaction, this approach significantly reduces the reliance on noble metal catalysts [16]. Among various non-noble metal catalytic systems, Zr-based organic-inorganic hybrid catalysts have attracted considerable attention due to their low cost, facile synthesis, and excellent catalytic performance. Wang et al. synthesized a magnetic, biomass-derived, acid-base bifunctional zirconium-based hybrid catalyst via a solvothermal method, utilizing magnetic iron oxide and furan-2,5-dicarboxylic acid. Under optimized reaction conditions of 180 °C for 5 hours, the catalytic conversion of ethyl levulinate EL to GVL achieved a yield of 94.5 % [17]. Li et al. developed a novel zirconium-based catalyst incorporating phenolic moieties, phenolic hydroxyl groups, and carboxyl functionalities by co-precipitating natural gallic acid with ZrCl4. Under reaction conditions of 160 °C for 8 hours, the catalyst facilitated the conversion of EL to GVL with a yield of 94.2 % [18]. Catalytic transfer hydrogenation of butyl levulinate to GVL over zirconium phosphates with adjustable Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [19]. Although these catalysts can achieve high yields (approximately 94 %), their preparation methods still have shortcomings. They often require the use of expensive ligands (such as FDCA, which has a more complex production process and low natural content, 220 USD/kg), high temperatures, longer reaction times, and non-aqueous solvents (such as N, N-dimethylformamide, ethanol, or ethyl acetate), which increase production costs and pose environmental risks. Additionally, the organic ligands used are not always fully sustainable, thereby limiting the overall green performance of these systems. In this study, malic acid (a biomass platform molecule derived from fruits and other sources, a naturally abundant and renewable organic acid with a cost of approximately 22 USD/kg) was used as a ligand to synthesize zirconium-based coordination polymer catalysts via a hydrothermal method. By using water as the sole solvent, the protocol conforms to green chemistry principles, minimizes organic solvent consumption and environmental burden, streamlines the process, enhances operational safety, and reduces production cost. By using water as the sole solvent, this protocol aligns with green chemistry principles. Compared to traditional zirconium-based catalysts (such as ZrO2/Al2O3, which typically require high-temperature calcination >500 °C) [20], it reduces organic solvent consumption and environmental impact, simplifies the process flow, enhances operational safety, and lowers production costs. Based on this optimized catalyst, a series of single-factor experiments were conducted to systematically investigate the effects of reaction temperature, catalyst loading, and reaction time, ultimately affording improved conversion and selectivity. Detailed kinetic analysis of reaction rate features further illuminated the underlying mechanism. This work offers new insights into the design of bifunctional metal-organic polymer catalysts and establishes both theoretical and experimental foundations for the aqueous solvothermal synthesis of green catalytic materials. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Ethyl levulinate (EL, 99 %), γ-valerolactone (GVL, 98 %), zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl4, 98 %), Malic acid (MA, 99.5 %), and dodecane (99 %) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Methanol (AR), ethanol (95 %), n-propanol (AR), n-butanol (AR), isopropanol (AR), sodium bicarbonate (AR), potassium hydrogen phthalate (AR), phenolphthalein (AR), and sodium hydroxide (AR) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Hydrochloric acid was purchased from Hunan Huihong Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalysts preparation MA (0.146 g) was dissolved in 20 mL of deionized water in a 50 mL beaker. Separately, ZrCl4 (0.518 g) was dissolved in 20 mL of deionized water. The two solutions were combined and stirred until a homogeneous mixture formed. This slurry was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 160 °C for 24 h. Upon completion, the autoclave was cooled to ambient temperature in an ice-water bath. The resulting suspension was poured into a beaker, homogenized by stirring, and the precipitate isolated by vacuum filtration. The solid was washed three times each with deionized water and ethanol, then dried overnight at 60 °C under vacuum to ensure complete removal of ethanol. Finally, the dry material was ground in an agate mortar to yield a fine powder, denoted Zr-MA0.5. An analogous hydrothermal procedure was employed to synthesize a series of catalysts by systematically varying the quantities of ZrCl4 and MA. Each material is designated Zr x −MA y , where x and y correspond to the respective molar amounts of ZrCl4 and malic acid introduced. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with a Zeiss Sigma 300 microscope. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were measured using a Rigaku Ultima IV with Cu Kα radiation, scanning in the range of 2θ = 5° to 90°, under conditions of 40 kV and 30 mA, with a scanning rate of 10°/minute. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected at room temperature in transmission mode using a NEXUS spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The spectra were recorded over the 400–4000 cm−1 range, with 20 scans per spectrum. The samples were prepared by the KBr pellet method, with a sample-to-KBr mass ratio of 1:100. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of the samples were recorded with a Netzsch STA 409 PC thermogravimetric analyzer (Germany), using a temperature ramp rate of 10 °C/min up to 800 °C. The Zr content in the Zr-based catalysts was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) using a Thermo Fisher ICAP 7200 device. The samples underwent microwave digestion pretreatment. The Zr content was calculated from a standard curve based on known concentrations of zirconium in concentrated nitric acid (68 %, w/w). Prior to analysis, 0.12 g of catalyst was treated with 10 mL of concentrated nitric acid (68 %, w/w) and preheated at 160 °C for 3 h. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements of the catalysts were performed using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer (USA). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained with a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. Pyridine-adsorbed FTIR spectra (Py-FTIR) were analyzed on Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer to differentiate the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites of the samples. The area of the two absorption peaks near 1450 and 1540 cm−1 was used to determine the amount of Brønsted and Lewis acids in the materials. The surface acidity of the catalysts was measured using the Boehm titration method, as outlined in the literature. Solutions of 0.1 M NaOH, NaHCO3, and HCl were prepared and standardized with primary standard solutions. After standardization, 0.05 g (m1) of each sample was soaked in 25 mL of 0.1 M NaOH or NaHCO3 solution and left to stand for 24 h. The suspensions were then titrated with 0.1 M HCl. Each sample was titrated in triplicate. The amounts of acidic carboxyl and phenolic hydroxyl groups were calculated using the following formulas [21]. (1) η carboxyl ( mmol / g ) = 25 × C N a H C O 3 − V H C l × C H C l m 1 (2) η phenol ( mmol / g ) = 25 × C N a O H − V H C l × C H C l m 1 − η carboxyl 2.4 Procedure for catalytic reaction The catalytic experiments were conducted in a 100 mL cylindrical stainless steel high-pressure reactor equipped with an external temperature controller and a mechanical stirrer (Jingkou Dantu Universal Electromechanical Accessories Factory, Zhenjiang). Typically, the reactor contained 1 mmol EL, 0.1 g catalyst, 10 mL IPA as a hydrogen donor and solvent, and 0.2 mmol n-dodecane as a standard. After sealing, the mixture was purged with nitrogen five times. The reaction was then heated to the desired temperature while stirring at 450 rpm, maintaining the necessary reaction time. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature using cold water. The liquid phase products were analyzed using gas chromatography and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. 2.5 Analytical method Determination and qualitative analysis of GVL and IPL were conducted using a Shimadzu gas chromatograph (GC 2030). Dodecane was used as an internal standard for GC analysis. The conversion of EL (CEL), the selectivity for GVL (SGVL), and the selectivity for IPL (SIPL) were calculated using the following formulas: (3) EL conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − F i n a l m o l e o f E L I n i t i a l m o l e o f E L ) × 100 % (4) Product yield ( % ) = M o l e o f p r o d u c t I n i t i a l m o l e o f E L × 100 % (5) Product selectivity ( % ) = P r o d u c t y i e l d E L c o n v e r s i o n × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts This study seeks to optimize the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst by precisely modulating the molar ratio between ZrCl4 and the MA ligand, with the ultimate goal of enhancing catalytic performance. To this end, the morphological characteristics and pore structure of the catalysts were systematically characterized using SEM in conjunction with BET surface area and porosity analyses. As illustrated in Fig. 1 a and 1b, the catalyst exhibits a relatively smooth surface morphology. With a further decrease in the molar ratio of MA, the surface of the Zr-MA0.5 sample became markedly rougher. Although its specific surface area exhibited a slight reduction compared to that of Zr-MA, the pore volume increased significantly to 0.457 cm3/g, and the pore size doubled to 62.4 nm. These combined features render it the material with the most favorable overall physical properties among all the samples. This phenomenon may be attributed to the insufficient amount of MA ligand, which hinders effective coordination among the smaller structural fragments during synthesis, thereby impeding the formation of a stable and integrated framework. Upon reducing the amount of Zr precursor, the surface morphology of the Zr0.5−MA0.5 sample reverted to a state resembling that of Zr-MA. However, when the molar ratio of MA is decreased to even lower levels, the insufficient ligand content results in the growth of larger catalyst particles. Consequently, both the specific surface area and pore volume decrease markedly, reaching 233.04 m2/g and 0.129 cm3/g, respectively [22]. As shown in Fig. 2 b and 2c, the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the Zr0.5−MA0.5 and Zr-MA samples exhibit typical Type IV curves with H4-type hysteresis loops, according to the classification criteria of the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC). This indicates the presence of slit-like pores formed by the aggregation of lamellar (plate-like) particles. In contrast, the isotherm of the Zr-MA0.5 sample displays a characteristic Type V shape accompanied by an H3-type hysteresis loop, which is typical of mesoporous materials and indicates that adsorption saturation is not achieved at high relative pressures. Additionally, the isotherms of Zr-MA0.3 and Zr-MA2 belong to Type I, with no obvious hysteresis loops observed, suggesting that their pore structures are predominantly microporous. Taking Zr0.5−MA0.5 as an example, TEM and SEM combined with elemental mapping analyses reveal that Zr, C, and O are uniformly distributed throughout both the surface and the interior of the catalyst. This demonstrates the feasibility of the water-based synthesis strategy and indicates that no metal aggregation occurs (see Fig. 1f, 1 g and Figure S1). Accordingly, both excessive and insufficient amounts of ligand can negatively impact the specific surface area and pore structure of the catalyst, thereby reducing its mass transfer efficiency during catalytic reactions. Generally, a higher specific surface area facilitates the formation of more acid-base active sites. Accordingly, among the tested samples, Zr-MA, Zr-MA0.5, and Zr0.5−MA0.5 exhibit superior overall porous structure properties. As shown in Fig. 2a, the XRD patterns of Zr x −MA y coordination polymer catalysts prepared at different molar ratios exhibit a broad diffraction feature between 2θ= 5° and 10°, with its maximum at approximately 6.7° The absence of any sharp Bragg reflections confirms that these materials are predominantly amorphous [23,24]. The observed broad diffraction feature corroborates the irregular coordination between Zr4+ and MA and confirms the amorphous character of Zr x −MA y , in agreement with SEM observations. Such an amorphous framework is expected to expose a higher density of active sites, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Furthermore, although variations in the precursor ratios do not alter the overall propensity for amorphous phase formation, they may modulate the degree of short-range order, which in turn may affect catalytic performance. As illustrated in Fig. 2d, the material mass decreased progressively with increasing temperature. Upon reaching a constant mass, the residual mass reflected the relative zirconium content within the material. Notably, the variation in metal content did not exhibit a direct correlation with the change in ligand ratio used during catalyst preparation, indicating that the synthesized catalyst structures were not ordered. This observation is consistent with the XRD results. The TG profiles further resolve two principal weight-loss stages: the first, occurring between 96 °C and 130 °C, primarily reflects desorption of physiosorbed water and removal of surface hydroxyl groups [25]. The second mass-loss event, spanning 358 °C to 469 °C, reflects decomposition of surface carboxyl functionalities. Notably, Zr-MA0.3 exhibits a higher decomposition onset within this interval, implying that reducing the malic acid ratio enhances thermal robustness. Furthermore, integration of data from Table 1 and Table S1 reveals that elevated MA loading increases the abundance of uncoordinated carboxyl groups on the catalyst surface, thereby promoting more extensive decarboxylation to CO2 during thermal decomposition [26]. Moreover, TG-DTG analysis demonstrates that deliberate variation of the acid-ligand molar ratio provides precise control over catalyst thermal stability. These insights furnish a valuable framework for further optimization of catalyst performance. Fig. 2f presents a comparison of infrared spectral features for various catalysts. A broad absorption band centered at approximately 3400 cm−1 can be attributed to O-H stretching vibrations of surface hydroxyl groups. The peak observed at 1105 cm−1 corresponds to C-O stretching vibrations. Upon introduction of Zr, a new band appears at 688 cm−1, arising from Zr-O bond stretching and thereby confirming formation of a coordination structure between Zr and MA [17,27,28]. The absorption at 1498 cm−1 results from coupling between COO− stretching and C-O-H bending vibrations, which indicates coordination of carboxyl groups, while hydroxyl functionalities primarily engage in hydrogen bonding or weak coordination interactions [29,30]. With increasing ligand loading, intermolecular esterification becomes apparent, giving rise to characteristic C-O-C stretching bands in the 1064–1012 cm−1 region; these features are most pronounced in the Zr-MA2 catalyst. Furthermore, metal coordination and intermolecular esterification modify the electron density of the carboxyl C=O bond, leading to a strong absorption near 1780 cm−1. Uncoordinated, free carboxyl groups constitute Brønsted acid sites, thus providing essential active centers for catalytic processes. To further elucidate the acidic characteristics of the material, XPS and Py-FTIR were applied for systematic catalyst analysis. As shown in Fig. 3 a, the Zr 3d spectrum features two principal binding energy peaks at 185.3 eV (Zr 3d3/2) and 182.9 eV (Zr 3d5/2). Although reduction of the ligand content induced a slight decrease in Zr 3d binding energies, these values remained considerably higher than those reported for bulk ZrO2 (Zr 3d3/2 at 184.3 eV and Zr 3d5/2 at 181.9 eV) [31], thereby implying enhanced Lewis acidity of zirconium species within Zr x −MA y catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 3b, deconvolution of the C 1s spectrum yields three distinct peaks at 284.8 eV, 286.5 eV, and 288.8 eV, which correspond to C-C/C-H, C-O, and O-C=O species, respectively. A progressive increase in MA content leads to a concomitant rise in the relative intensities of the C-O and O-C=O components, thereby corroborating an elevated surface concentration of carboxyl functionalities. In Fig. 3c, the O 1s spectrum can be resolved into three peaks at 531.7 eV, 532.9 eV, and 527.8 eV, attributable to -Zr-O, C-O, and C=O bonds, respectively [32]. SEM analysis revealed that the reduction of ligand loading led to an increase in catalyst particle size. This phenomenon is attributed to the complete coordination of carboxyl groups with metal ions, which consequently diminishes the population of free surface carboxyl. As a result, Py-FTIR spectra of Zr-MA0.3 failed to exhibit a discernible Brønsted acid band, thereby reinforcing the proposed coordination-driven mechanism. Using Zr-MA0.5 as a representative example, the catalyst exhibits both a high density of Lewis acid sites and a spectrum of Brønsted acid sites [33]. Quantitative analysis indicates Lewis acid site density of 9.36 mmol/gcat, marginally lower than the 12.66 mmol/gcat, observed for Zr-MA2 (Table S2), whereas Brønsted acid density reaches 3.49 mmol/gcat, resulting in a Brønsted-to-Lewis ratio of 0.37. Such a balanced acid-site architecture is anticipated to enhance both hydrogenation and lactonization steps during the catalytic conversion of EL to GVL [34]. 3.2 Catalytic test Selection of an effective catalyst is critical for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of EL to GVL. Among common dicarboxylic acid ligands, several typical ones were selected for comparison, with the data shown in Table S3. When malic acid was used as the ligand, the catalytic effect was optimal. Considering factors such as the source of the ligand, cost, and environmental friendliness, malic acid was selected as the ligand. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the impact of different feedstock ratios on catalytic performance was evaluated under identical reaction conditions. With a constant zirconium precursor, decreasing the ligand loading from 3 to 0.3 resulted in an initial increase in EL conversion followed by a slight decline, while GVL selectivity remained consistently high at over 93 %. This behavior can be attributed to an increase in defect sites as ligand proportion decreases. However, once ligand loading falls below a certain threshold, SEM and BET analyses reveal deterioration of pore structure and particle size distribution, which in turn adversely affects catalytic performance. This further demonstrates that different ratios of malic acid to zirconium can affect the structure of the catalyst, thereby influencing its catalytic performance. In comparison, Zr-MA0.5 exhibited the most superior catalytic performance, achieving an EL conversion of 98.3 % and a GVL selectivity of 93.9 %. Building on this formulation, reducing the Zr content increases the coordination number between Zr and carboxyl groups, thereby augmenting the Lewis acid site density [35]. Given the notable catalytic performance of Zr-MA0.5, this material was subjected to single-variable investigation. As illustrated in Fig. 4b, an increase in reaction temperature resulted in a progressive rise in EL conversion, while GVL selectivity remained consistently high; thus, elevated temperature appears to facilitate reaction progression. At 170 °C, EL conversion and GVL selectivity attained maximum values of 98.3 % and 93.9 %, respectively. Under conditions of 170 °C and a 3 h reaction time, catalyst loading was varied in 25 mg increments (Fig. 4c). As the amount of the catalyst increases, both EL conversion and GVL selectivity gradually increase, implying that a higher density of acid sites promotes the catalytic process. In the time-dependent study (Fig. 4d), the selectivity of GVL reached its maximum value after 3 h; as the reaction time was further extended, the selectivity decreased slightly, which may be due to secondary conversions that generated other compounds [36], such as 1,4-pentanediol [37], 2-methyl tetrahydrofuran [38], valeric acid/ester [39], 5-nonanone [40], and butene [41]. In the transfer hydrogenation reaction, alcohols act as both solvents and hydrogen donors. Under consistent reaction conditions, Figure S2 investigates the effect of different alcohols on the conversion of EL to GVL. Methanol, as a hydrogen donor, achieves a high EL conversion rate, but due to significant side reactions (particularly ester exchange to form methyl ethyl acetoacetate), it results in low GVL selectivity. Ethanol achieves moderate EL conversion rates with higher GVL selectivity, attributed to reduced ester exchange reactions. Other primary alcohols, such as n-propanol and n-butanol, exhibit lower performance due to their weaker reducing potential compared to secondary alcohols. However, isopropanol demonstrates excellent EL conversion rates and GVL selectivity, benefiting from its lower reducing potential, making it the most effective hydrogen donor in this reaction[42]. 3.3 Kinetic study Based on prior research findings and a comprehensive analysis of the experimental data, two plausible pathways have been proposed for the synthesis of GVL from EL via CTH. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , the first pathway involves the direct conversion of EL to GVL through a sequential process comprising CTH reduction followed by intramolecular lactonization. Alternatively, the second pathway proceeds via an initial transesterification reaction between EL and isopropanol, forming isopropyl levulinate (IPL), which subsequently undergoes CTH reduction and lactonization to afford GVL [43]. In the study of the effects of various reaction parameters on the conversion of EL to GVL, reaction temperature was found to exert a pronounced influence on GVL selectivity (Fig. 4a). Therefore, kinetic experiments were conducted at 120 °C, 130 °C, and 140 °C. Given that isopropanol served both as solvent and hydrogen source and was employed in large excess, slight variations in its concentration exerted negligible effects on overall reaction rate. Consequently, isopropanol concentration was maintained constant and reaction kinetics were modeled using a pseudo-first-order approach [44]. The differential equation governing the process is as follows: d C E L d t = − ( k 1 + k 2 ) · C E L d C I P L d t = k 2 · C E L − k 3 · C I P L d C G V L d t = k 1 · C I P L + k 3 · C E L In this formulation, C denotes the molar concentration of each species, whereas k i corresponds to the apparent rate constant under isothermal conditions. The fitting quality is quantified by computing residuals between calculated and experimental concentrations of each species at various reaction times; consequently, a lower value of the objective function F obj signifies a more accurate fit. Specifically, Cm, n, Calc. and Cm, n, exp. denote, respectively, the calculated and experimental concentrations of species m (for example, EL, IPA, and GVL) at the n time point. F o b j = ∑ m { ∑ n = 1 n p [ C m , n , c a l c − C m , n , e x p ] 2 } By fitting the experimental data, apparent rate constants at the temperatures listed in Table 2 were determined, and the objective function values (F obj ) were employed to evaluate the agreement between the kinetic model and the experimental observations. At 120 °C, 130 °C, and 140 °C, F obj values of 3.12×10−5, 2.01×10−4, and 2.60×10−4, respectively, demonstrate that the constructed kinetic model accurately reproduces the actual reaction behavior. Moreover, the close correspondence between experimental data points and model-predicted concentration profiles (Fig. 5 a-c) further confirms the reliability and scientific validity of the fitting results. As reaction temperature increases, all apparent rate constants rise in accordance with the temperature-dependence predicted by chemical kinetics. At each of the three temperatures, the apparent rate constant k1 for EL → GVL considerably exceeds k₂ for EL→ IPL and k3 for IPL → GVL, indicating that EL predominantly undergoes transfer hydrogenation and lactonization to yield GVL. At the same time, elevated temperature favors ester interchange to generate IPL. For example, at 140 °C, k2 reaches 6.0 × 10−3 h−1, approximately twice the value observed at 120 °C. Apparent activation energies for each reaction step were calculated using the Arrhenius equation (Fig. 5d-f). Because EL and IPL possess similar physicochemical properties, their activation energies for conversion to GVL are also comparable, measuring 101.02 kJ/mol and 105.33 kJ/mol, respectively. In contrast, the activation energy associated with EL → GVL via ester interchange alone is substantially lower, at 46.97 kJ/mol [45–47]. 3.4 Catalyst stability The reusability of heterogeneous catalysts plays a pivotal role in determining their feasibility for practical applications. To this end, the recyclability of the Zr-MA0.5 catalyst was systematically evaluated. As illustrated in Fig. 6 a, the catalyst maintained high catalytic activity over at least six consecutive reaction cycles, with only a marginal decline in performance, thereby demonstrating excellent cycle stability. To further assess the structural integrity of the catalyst, FT-IR spectra of the catalyst after six cycles were compared with those of the fresh material, as shown in Figure S3. The minimal differences observed between the characteristic absorption bands indicate that the catalyst structure remained largely intact throughout the recycling process. In addition, leaching experiments depicted in Fig. 6b revealed that the reaction ceased immediately upon removal of the catalyst from the reaction mixture. This observation confirms the absence of significant leaching of active species during the catalytic process. Collectively, these results highlight the outstanding reusability and structural robustness of the Zr-MA0.5 catalyst in the hydrogenation of EL to GVL, underscoring its potential as a promising and efficient catalytic system for biomass valorization. 3.5 Tolerance assessment To assess the suitability of the catalyst under actual biomass-derived feedstock conditions, we added typical impurities—water, acetic acid, and furan—at concentrations of 1–10 vol % to high-purity EL and tested them under the same reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 7 , furan only caused a gradual decrease in EL conversion, while GVL selectivity remained above 89 %, indicating minimal interference with the reaction pathway. In contrast, acetic acid significantly reduced the conversion rate (approximately 22–25 %) and shifted the product distribution toward IPL. This is attributed to acetic acid competing with Zr⁴⁺ sites for coordination and promoting acid-catalyzed ester exchange reactions. Water caused moderate and gradual decreases in both conversion rate and GVL selectivity, while IPL production increased, consistent with the blocking of Zr–OH sites and shifts in the hydrolysis/esterification equilibrium. These results indicate that the catalyst exhibits good tolerance toward furan but is more sensitive to strong acids and water, emphasizing the importance of raw material pretreatment in crude EL processing for achieving optimal GVL yield. Additionally, it demonstrates that the catalyst described in this study maintains good catalytic activity even in the presence of small amounts of non-acidic impurities. 3.6 Reaction mechanism According to literature reports, when ZrCl4 is employed as the metal precursor and malic acid serves as the coordinating ligand in aqueous solution, Zr4+ ions do not stabilize in the form of the Zr6O4(OH)4 secondary building unit commonly observed in UiO-type metal-organic frameworks [48,49]. Instead, they tend to self-assemble into a Zr4 cluster, in which four zirconium atoms are bridged through μ₃-oxo linkages. Based on experimental observations, prior studies, and the schematic illustration in Fig. 8 , a catalytic mechanism is proposed for the transformation of EL into GVL over the Zr-MA framework [50]. Initially, isopropanol adsorbs onto the active sites of the Zr4 cluster, where it undergoes cleavage under the synergistic action of Zr4+-O2− acid-base pairs, generating alkoxide species and transferring a hydrogen atom to the cluster oxygen, thereby completing hydrogen donor activation. Subsequently, the EL molecule coordinates to an adjacent zirconium center via its carbonyl group and undergoes hydrogenation through a cyclic transition state (TS1), yielding an intermediate of 4-hydroxypentanoate ester [51]. Following the desorption of acetone as a byproduct, the resulting Zr defect site becomes available for coordination with the ester carbonyl group, providing an activation site for the subsequent lactonization step. The intermediate undergoes intramolecular nucleophilic attack via a second transition state (TS2), forming a five-membered ring and giving rise to the lactonized intermediate. Finally, under the influence of Zr4+-O2− acid–base pairs, a molecule of ethanol is eliminated through a third transition state (TS3), affording the final product GVL. This mechanistic proposal elucidates the functional roles of the Zr4 cluster in the sequential steps of hydrogen activation, carbonyl hydrogenation, and lactonization, thereby offering theoretical guidance for the rational design of efficient Zr-based catalysts [52–54]. 4 Conclusions In summary, this work synthesized a highly efficient and economical zirconium-malic acid coordination polymer, Zr-MA0.5, with a green, aqueous synthesis method. This catalyst exhibits a high specific surface area coupled with a well-developed mesoporous network, thereby enhancing mass transfer during reaction. In addition, it features abundant Lewis acid sites alongside pronounced Brønsted acidity, and the balanced Brønsted-to-Lewis acid ratio underlies its exceptional performance in the transfer hydrogenation of biomass-derived EL to GVL. Experimental and kinetic investigations reveal that judiciously elevated temperatures accelerate substrate conversion; however, temperatures beyond the optimal threshold prolong the reaction pathway and exacerbate undesired by-product generation. Besides, a mechanistic model was proposed to clarify the functional roles of the Zr active sites in hydrogen activation, carbonyl hydrogenation, and subsequent lactonization, thereby providing theoretical insight for the rational development of high-performance Zr-based catalytic system. Moreover, the catalyst maintained high catalytic efficiency over at least six consecutive cycles without generating contamination during either synthesis or reaction processes. Furthermore, the aqueous solution synthesis strategy used to prepare Zr-MA0.5 is highly scalable, as it relies on inexpensive precursors, mild reaction conditions, and no toxic solvents. Although further optimization of reactor design and process intensification may be required, the simplicity and environmental friendliness of this method highlight its strong potential for industrial conversion. These results embody the principles of green chemistry and underscore the immense potential of this catalyst in sustainable and environmentally friendly chemical transformations. coredata.dc:description: The development of green, efficient, and economical catalysts for the transformation of biomass into value-added chemicals is vital for advancing sustainable chemical manufacturing. In this work, a series of cost-effective and stable zirconium-based catalysts were synthesized via coordination of Zr4+ with malic acid (MA), a low-cost and naturally abundant organic ligand, in aqueous solution. By precisely tuning the ligand-to-metal molar ratio, the porous structure properties of the resulting materials could be finely controlled. In addition, the Brønsted-to-Lewis acid site ratio reached 0.37, indicating a well-balanced acidic environment. These structural and acidic characteristics collectively contributed to its superior catalytic performance in the conversion of ethyl levulinate (EL) to γ-valerolactone (GVL) via transfer hydrogenation and intramolecular lactonization. Kinetic analysis revealed that elevated temperatures promote the direct transformation of EL to GVL; however, temperatures beyond the optimal range induce competing transesterification reactions, thereby extending the reaction pathway. Notably, the catalyst retained its activity over at least six consecutive cycles without detectable deactivation. A mechanistic framework is proposed to provide deeper insight into the transfer hydrogenation process mediated by this class of Zr-based coordination catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Zirconium-malate coordination polymer: a green catalyst for transfer hydrogenation of Ethyl Levulinate to Synthesize γ-valerolactone
